Lesson Narrative

This lesson introduces students to function notation. Students encounter situations in which referencing certain functions and their input-output pairs gets complicated, wordy, or unclear. This motivates a way to talk about functions that is more concise and precise.

Students learn that function notation is a succinct way to name a function and to specify its input and output. They interpret function notation in terms of the quantities in a situation and use function notation to represent simple statements about a function. The work in this lesson prompts students to reason quantitatively and abstractly and communicate precisely.

Learning Goals (Teacher Facing)

Students will be able to:

  • Interpret statements that use function notation and explain (orally and in writing) their meaning in terms of a situation.
  • Understand that function notation is a succinct way to name a function and specify its input and output.
  • Use function notation to express functions with specific inputs and outputs.

Learning Targets (Student Facing)

  • Use function notation to express functions that have specific inputs and outputs.
  • Explain what function notation is and why it exists.
  • Explain a statement written in function notation in terms of a situation.

Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills (TEKS)

TEKS

Explanation of Coverage

A12(A) decide whether relations represented verbally, tabularly, graphically, and symbolically define a function; define a function;


A12(B) evaluate functions, expressed in function notation, given one or more elements in their domains;

Partial coverage: Lesson provides content that covers part of this TEKS. The parts that are covered have been underlined.


Foundational: Lesson provides foundational content necessary for students to be able to perform this TEKS in later lessons.

Lesson Activities

Here are the instructional activities for the lesson:

  • 4.2.1: Interpreting Graphs to Answer Questions
  • 4.2.2: Interpreting Statements Written in Function Notation
  • 4.2.2: Self Check
  • 4.2.3: Finding a Unique Output for Each Input
  • 4.2.3: Self Check
  • 4.2.4: Understanding Function Notation Using Application Problems

Students will also complete a series of problems in the 4.2.5: Practice.

Required Materials

None

Required Preparation

None

Lesson Vocabulary

During this lesson, it is important to:

  • Familiarize students with the vocabulary words they will see throughout the lesson. Encourage students to look for these words and notice their use and meanings.
  • Encourage students to use key vocabulary words in “math talk” and their written and oral explanations.
  • Utilize a word wall. Sample cards are located here: Mathematics Vocabulary Word Wall Cards

Vocabulary words that are emphasized in this lesson include:

Previous Vocabulary

  • function
  • relation

New Vocabulary

None
